text.author: John Hooper
text.description: Italian premier believes his wife fell into a trap organised by his political opponents
text.title: Berlusconi claims his divorce was 'incited' by the opposition

main.p: Silvio Berlusconi's high-profile separation from his wife took a political twist as he and the leader of Italy's biggest opposition party clashed over who, if anyone, had encouraged her to file for divorce.

The row erupted after the prime minister told an interviewer that his second wife, Veronica Lario, should apologise to him for her behaviour â€“ and not the other way round. In an interview with Italy's biggest-selling daily, Corriere della Sera, Berlusconi also implied that he was the victim of a plot hatched by his enemies.
"I am indignant," Berlusconi said. "Veronica has fallen into a trap. And I know who she is being advised by. Or rather, being incited by."
He added darkly: "The truth will come out, don't worry."

Dario Franceschini, the leader of the centre-left Democratic Party hit back, saying the prime minister's insinuation was "pathetic". He said: "We have acted like responsible people in this matter, leaving a personal matter out of politics."

The already distressed Berlusconi-Lario match headed for the rocks after the prime minister was reported to have attended the 18th birthday party of a girl from Naples who aspires to a career as a model and says that she calls him "Daddy". Writing angrily to a news agency afterwards, Lario concentrated her fire on her husband's selection of a string of pretty young women, including a Big Brother contestant, to be candidates for his party in next month's European parliamentary election. In an aside that was reported to have particularly riled the 72-year-old, his wife was later quoted as saying she could no longer remain married to "a man who frequents minors".

Asked if there was any chance of saving his marriage, the prime minister said: "I don't think so. I don't know if I want that this time. Veronica will have to apologise to me publicly. And I don't know if it would be enough ... It's the third time in an election campaign that she has pulled a stunt of this kind. It really is too much."

Yesterday's interview appeared to mark the launch of a vigorous counter-offensive by the Berlusconi camp, concerned that the shattering of the prime minister's marriage to the 52 year-old Lario could have widespread political fall-out. According to other reports yesterday, Berlusconi's aides fear his scorned wife might launch an all-out campaign against him, revealing embarrassing secrets and sensitive information, in interviews with magazines and TV chat shows.

A leading pollster, Renato Mannheimer, said: "I don't think that it will take votes away from the prime minister because there are other reasons why [his supporters] vote for him." But other commentators speculated that the matter could lose Berlusconi support among women and devout Catholics.
Corriere said the prime minister believed he was the victim of a plot to ruin him at the apex of his popularity.
The paper also quoted him as saying the affair was a result of "media criminality", and that he believed key details had been misrepresented.

Berlusconi said he had dropped in on the birthday party of young Noemi Letizia because her father, a lowly council messenger, was a "friend of many years". Asked why she called him papi, he replied: "But it's a joke. They wanted to call me granddad. It's better they call me daddy, don't you think?"
One of several mysteries surrounding the row is how a billionaire television and property magnate came to be such a close associate of Letizia's father.

Berlusconi was originally quoted by news agencies as saying that Benedetto Letizia had been a chauffeur for his friend, Italy's disgraced former prime minister, the late Bettino Craxi. But after journalists established that Letizia had never worked for Craxi, the prime minister's office issued a statement denying he had ever made such an assertion.
